story:
Busby BE-62 All Tube Audio Mixer (3D Rendering by Kenn Danner of KD Design)


A note to those whose first, second, or third love is not audio recording equipment:

Although you may not understand the language used below, you have all been influenced by the sound of good quality audio that used vacuum tube amplifiers, regardless of what genre of music was your favourite. For this reason, we've included the song/music files as a perk for your contribution. We'll keep building the library of music that is available through the special link you'll receive when you contribute $10 or more to the Busby campaign.

Our Story

Busby Electronics was started three years ago, although seeds for the idea were planted in the early 1980s when Donn Tarris owned, for a brief time, one of the rare Universal Audio 610 modular mixing consoles. These recording consoles, designed and built by Bill Putnam Sr were to become one of the most sought after mixers from the vacuum tube era. To recording engineers, these offered the bar to which other audio preamps were measured up to.

Unfortunately, the console was in very poor shape, and a decision was made to trade the modules to a dealer in San Francisco who could place them into studios around the US as single channels of preamplification.


From this:


The original 2005 design of the ArMod (originally called the TiMod)

To this:


The new 2011 design of the ArMod


Fast forward to 2008. After three years of modifying vintage audio preamps purchased off ebay (see ArMod original 2005 design above) and reselling them, Donn was finally ready to pursue the design of a new multi-channel audio mixer based on the best 1960s vacuum tube design. Largely driven by the desire to have a compact mixer that could feed the missing six channels of microphone preamplifiers in many eight channel digital audio interfaces, He spent a year studying vintage designs of preamps in books from the late 1950s and early 1960s. A business plan was formulated and investors approached to raise funds for completing the design of every component that would go into the mixer. A definite set of criteria was included in the plan:


  1. The design had to incorporate the best of ideas from the early 1960s along with the flexibility required in a modern recording studio. The gain structure had to be able to be set to mimic that of a late 1950s console, or set to allow for maximum headroom, low noise, and accurate amplification - all by the choice of the recording engineer.
  2. The design was to be based on a selection of tubes that was not ubiquitous.
  3. The design should use as many locally available parts as possible - first within the local community, then from the province, then the country, then from other countries with similar economic circumstance. This was to ensure as many jobs as possible stayed in each of these geographic areas. Whenever possible, parts would be made locally within Busby's own shop. This currently includes all metal work, printed circuit boards, paint, and even the casting of the custom control knobs!
  4. The products must be able to be repaired in the field, to reduce shipping costs, as well as the amount of time needed to affect repairs. All design has this in mind to ensure that the equipment is easy to work on, and that parts are more readily available. No solid state or integrated circuits are used within the signal path. ICs are only used in the regulation of power and for the headphone amp. All other circuits are simple vacuum tube circuits using relatively commonly available parts.
  5. The products would not be sold just as hardware. In 1979 Donn was involved in starting the first school for recording arts aimed at project studio operators. He designed the initial courses for record engineering and production, giving students a solid base from which to carry on learning. The concepts covered in those initial courses is still relevant today, and will be made available to Busby customers through the web site.



Busby 2Rack prototype


Today Busby is set up to build from the designs that have been created and tested over the past two and a half years. Prototypes have been built and used on demo recordings. Feedback is found on the Busby web site from industry professionals who have tested the circuit in the form of the Busby 2Rack dual channel preamp and have been blown away. Initial orders have been received from around the world.

The Impact

Busby Electronics is pure cottage industry. As much of the work as possible is done in our own shop, with sourcing starting locally and moving outward from there - Town, Province, Country, Continent...

The philosophy behind building products designed to last several lifetimes ensures an impact in many areas of artistic, business, and even ecological environments.


What We Need

Busby Electronics is looking to raise $15,000 to improve our equipment and provide training to the people doing the work on building the products we've designed.

When the company was first formed the idea was to do all design and final assembly in-house. The metal work, paint, and printed circuit boards would all be jobbed out to local firms with those capabilities. The only supplier of control knobs that would fit the design was located in Japan and, along with high cost and large minimum order requirements, the quality of the first samples was very poor. At the same time, the number of metal fabricators was reduced from before the beginning of the recession (did I mention that Busby was started at the beginning of the recession?) and even getting quotes in reasonable turnaround was a problem. Coupled with that, the charges for changes to the design would be prohibitive and not allow for the level of customization that Donn wanted to be able to offer customers.

To get around the uncertainty of turnarounds, quality, and availability of specialized fabrication, research was done into the state of the DIY (Do It Yourself) CNC (Computer Numeric Controlled) metal cutting machines, as well as other equipment necessary to do more of the work in-house. A suitable CNC router table kit was found, purchased and built. A metal shear and small box brake (bender) were purchased. A company in the US was located who could supply not only materials for casting urethane knobs, but they also had online video tutorials to help with the learning curve. A computer was purchased along with software to enable the design of printed circuit boards and all the metal work. The programs would also create the necessary code to drive the cnc machine. Two years and many broken bits later, the production shop is now able to be used for short run fabrication. During the two years of learning the ins and outs of circuit layout design and computerized metal fabrication, along with how to cast urethane and paint aluminum, new equipment has come available in the market that will improve the repeatability and speed of production. While we're very please with the quality of work we've managed to do with very "hobbyist" level equipment, we need more robust equipment to satisfy a real production schedule.

A new cnc machine complete with computer and software will cost us $5000 by the time it's delivered. A higher quality shear, box brake, and casting equipment will cost another $5000, with a fairly high percentage going to shipping costs as these are heavy industrial pieces. The balance of the money sought is to be used to cover the cost of training workers in the specialized tasks required to produce a high quality product, and the costs associated with Indiegogo.

As mentioned above at the end of "Our Story", we have seven orders for Busby products in the shop now. The balances paid upon completion of these orders covers the labour portion of the work, using trained workers. The funds raised through Indiegogo.com from the first four levels of perks (rewards) goes towards the $15,000 goal to cover what's mentioned above. The cost of the perks and the fees for Indiegogo account for about 15% of the funds collected.

When you donate for any level above the first four, approximately 75% goes to cover the direct cost of materials and wages to produce the perk product. The balance is added to the goal requirements. So, while we really appreciate it if you choose to contribute in return for the higher value perks, there are not as many funds raised directly towards our goal - but you will be forgiven :-), and appreciated as a true supporter and appreciator of fine quality North American made audio products!

If we don't meet our full fundraising goal, we will use what is collected to facilitate training first, then the replacement of the cnc machine. As soon as even one of the products ships to its intended destination, we're confident that other orders will be placed to allow us to continue production.

What You Get

Look at the side panel perks offered for your contributions, we've tried to offer something for everyone - music lover, tech/geek, musician, small or large studio owner. See if something there attracts your attention. You can also feel great knowing that you're helping a small North American manufacturer design and build good quality equipment that will help creators of the music and soundtracks that you listen to!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this link with friends, family, associates, acquaintances - anyone you think may be remotely interested. We appreciate all the help we get growing this small company!
story_txt:
Busby BE-62 All Tube Audio Mixer (3D Rendering by Kenn Danner of KD Design)

A note to those whose first, second, or third love is not audio recording equipment:
Although you may not understand the language used below, you have all been influenced by the sound of good quality audio that used vacuum tube amplifiers, regardless of what genre of music was your favourite. For this reason, we've included the song/music files as a perk for your contribution. We'll keep building the library of music that is available through the special link you'll receive when you contribute $10 or more to the Busby campaign.
Our Story
Busby Electronics was started three years ago, although seeds for the idea were planted in the early 1980s when Donn Tarris owned, for a brief time, one of the rare Universal Audio 610 modular mixing consoles. These recording consoles, designed and built by Bill Putnam Sr were to become one of the most sought after mixers from the vacuum tube era. To recording engineers, these offered the bar to which other audio preamps were measured up to.
Unfortunately, the console was in very poor shape, and a decision was made to trade the modules to a dealer in San Francisco who could place them into studios around the US as single channels of preamplification.

From this:


The original 2005 design of the ArMod (originally called the TiMod)

To this:

The new 2011 design of the ArMod

Fast forward to 2008. After three years of modifying vintage audio preamps purchased off ebay (see ArMod original 2005 design above) and reselling them, Donn was finally ready to pursue the design of a new multi-channel audio mixer based on the best 1960s vacuum tube design. Largely driven by the desire to have a compact mixer that could feed the missing six channels of microphone preamplifiers in many eight channel digital audio interfaces, He spent a year studying vintage designs of preamps in books from the late 1950s and early 1960s. A business plan was formulated and investors approached to raise funds for completing the design of every component that would go into the mixer. A definite set of criteria was included in the plan:



The design had to incorporate the best of ideas from the early 1960s along with the flexibility required in a modern recording studio. The gain structure had to be able to be set to mimic that of a late 1950s console, or set to allow for maximum headroom, low noise, and accurate amplification - all by the choice of the recording engineer.
The design was to be based on a selection of tubes that was not ubiquitous.

The design should use as many locally available parts as possible - first within the local community, then from the province, then the country, then from other countries with similar economic circumstance. This was to ensure as many jobs as possible stayed in each of these geographic areas. Whenever possible, parts would be made locally within Busby's own shop. This currently includes all metal work, printed circuit boards, paint, and even the casting of the custom control knobs!

The products must be able to be repaired in the field, to reduce shipping costs, as well as the amount of time needed to affect repairs. All design has this in mind to ensure that the equipment is easy to work on, and that parts are more readily available. No solid state or integrated circuits are used within the signal path. ICs are only used in the regulation of power and for the headphone amp. All other circuits are simple vacuum tube circuits using relatively commonly available parts.

The products would not be sold just as hardware. In 1979 Donn was involved in starting the first school for recording arts aimed at project studio operators. He designed the initial courses for record engineering and production, giving students a solid base from which to carry on learning. The concepts covered in those initial courses is still relevant today, and will be made available to Busby customers through the web site.





Busby 2Rack prototype

Today Busby is set up to build from the designs that have been created and tested over the past two and a half years. Prototypes have been built and used on demo recordings. Feedback is found on the Busby web site from industry professionals who have tested the circuit in the form of the Busby 2Rack dual channel preamp and have been blown away. Initial orders have been received from around the world.

The Impact
Busby Electronics is pure cottage industry. As much of the work as possible is done in our own shop, with sourcing starting locally and moving outward from there - Town, Province, Country, Continent...
The philosophy behind building products designed to last several lifetimes ensures an impact in many areas of artistic, business, and even ecological environments.

What We Need

Busby Electronics is looking to raise $15,000 to improve our equipment and provide training to the people doing the work on building the products we've designed.
When the company was first formed the idea was to do all design and final assembly in-house. The metal work, paint, and printed circuit boards would all be jobbed out to local firms with those capabilities. The only supplier of control knobs that would fit the design was located in Japan and, along with high cost and large minimum order requirements, the quality of the first samples was very poor. At the same time, the number of metal fabricators was reduced from before the beginning of the recession (did I mention that Busby was started at the beginning of the recession?) and even getting quotes in reasonable turnaround was a problem. Coupled with that, the charges for changes to the design would be prohibitive and not allow for the level of customization that Donn wanted to be able to offer customers.

To get around the uncertainty of turnarounds, quality, and availability of specialized fabrication, research was done into the state of the DIY (Do It Yourself) CNC (Computer Numeric Controlled) metal cutting machines, as well as other equipment necessary to do more of the work in-house. A suitable CNC router table kit was found, purchased and built. A metal shear and small box brake (bender) were purchased. A company in the US was located who could supply not only materials for casting urethane knobs, but they also had online video tutorials to help with the learning curve. A computer was purchased along with software to enable the design of printed circuit boards and all the metal work. The programs would also create the necessary code to drive the cnc machine. Two years and many broken bits later, the production shop is now able to be used for short run fabrication. During the two years of learning the ins and outs of circuit layout design and computerized metal fabrication, along with how to cast urethane and paint aluminum, new equipment has come available in the market that will improve the repeatability and speed of production. While we're very please with the quality of work we've managed to do with very "hobbyist" level equipment, we need more robust equipment to satisfy a real production schedule.

A new cnc machine complete with computer and software will cost us $5000 by the time it's delivered. A higher quality shear, box brake, and casting equipment will cost another $5000, with a fairly high percentage going to shipping costs as these are heavy industrial pieces. The balance of the money sought is to be used to cover the cost of training workers in the specialized tasks required to produce a high quality product, and the costs associated with Indiegogo.


As mentioned above at the end of "Our Story", we have seven orders for Busby products in the shop now. The balances paid upon completion of these orders covers the labour portion of the work, using trained workers. The funds raised through Indiegogo.com from the first four levels of perks (rewards) goes towards the $15,000 goal to cover what's mentioned above. The cost of the perks and the fees for Indiegogo account for about 15% of the funds collected.


When you donate for any level above the first four, approximately 75% goes to cover the direct cost of materials and wages to produce the perk product. The balance is added to the goal requirements. So, while we really appreciate it if you choose to contribute in return for the higher value perks, there are not as many funds raised directly towards our goal - but you will be forgiven :-), and appreciated as a true supporter and appreciator of fine quality North American made audio products!
If we don't meet our full fundraising goal, we will use what is collected to facilitate training first, then the replacement of the cnc machine. As soon as even one of the products ships to its intended destination, we're confident that other orders will be placed to allow us to continue production.
What You Get

Look at the side panel perks offered for your contributions, we've tried to offer something for everyone - music lover, tech/geek, musician, small or large studio owner. See if something there attracts your attention. You can also feel great knowing that you're helping a small North American manufacturer design and build good quality equipment that will help creators of the music and soundtracks that you listen to!

Other Ways You Can Help
Please share this link with friends, family, associates, acquaintances - anyone you think may be remotely interested. We appreciate all the help we get growing this small company!

story:
Who We Are:

IKURU is an ethical fashion label based in Pemba, a bustling town on the Indian Ocean in Northern Mozambique (www.ikuruproject.com). We are a small team with a big dream. IKURU means "strength" in the local Macua language, and providing strength to women through fashion is at the heart of the IKURU Project. In a converted workshop, we train and employ Mozambican women from vulnerable social and economic backgrounds to create original, handcrafted clothing for a living. We use the beautiful locally-sourced vibrant capulanas (African wax print fabrics) that accompany women’s everyday lives throughout Africa to make our trendy, everyday clothes for women, men and children.

Through fashion, IKURU helps single women with little formal work opportunities, low access to health and childcare services to rebuild their lives. We provide professional training and employment, subsidized childcare for their young ones, workshops on gender, sexual education, family planning and financial management, and a safe working environment where they can rebuild their confidence and, with their salaries and increased skills, better contribute to their and their families’ needs.

The current team of seamstresses is comprised of seven young women who are learning the trade from a talented tailor. July 2015 marked the one year anniversary of the women joining IKURU. A celebration was in order to mark this special achievement! The culmination of IKURU's hard work and beautiful clothing line were displayed in a tour de force fashion event at one of Pemba's notable venues. We hope this is just the beginning of our team –with time we would like to see our business and the social impact of its investment grow to empower even more women in Mozambique.

**Models from the July 2015 Fashion Show in Pemba, MZ

Why We Need YOUR Help:

For IKURU to grow as a business and employ and empower more women in Pemba, developing quality control and improving the management of the production line is critical. Given Mozambique's lack of textile and apparel production, the local skills to contribute to this capacity building are not available in Pemba. Therefore, IKURU is preparing to invite an expert design team (a designer and a professional seamstress) to Pemba in November to build the capacity of the production team. Through innovative workshops, the team will learn the design and production process from beginning to end and simultaneously prepare the IKURU label for its next collection to be launched in December 2015 at the Maputo Fashion Week (www.mfw.co.mz). By the end of the training visit, the team will have honed the skills needed to work on present and future collections, and will be empowered to take more ownership over the quality of their output.  

**The current team of seamstresses in their workshop in Pemba, MZ

Who is the Expert Design Team?

IKURU is honored to have the opportunity to work with 2 design experts- Thais Marquez, a Brazilian designer, and Ana Elisa, a professional seamstress and trainer who has worked alongside Marquez for years. Marquez is a designer who currently works in São Paulo, Brazil, as a consultant in strategic design. She has extensive experience working in innovative workshops for the training of artisans in Brazil and as a value chain expert in crafts in Mozambique. The seasoned seamstress will offer valuable hands-on training to the current IKURU team in Pemba. The design team will create new designs (patterns & sizes), train seamstresses on improved sewing skills and quality control, and ensure that each item that receives an IKURU label upholds the highest level of quality possible for handmade pieces.

**A few of IKURU's designs from the most recent collection.

Budget & Perks:

IKURU needs $20,000 to bring the label to the next level. The funds raised will allow the designer and seamstress team to come to Pemba, cover costs for food and lodging, provide a subsidy for their expertise and conduct intensive workshops with the local seamstresses, design a new collection, and purchase 2 sergers which are critically needed in order to raise the quality of IKURU's designs. We will keep you updated on our site and facebook page about the funds we have raised and how we have used them!

We appreciate your contributions to the campaign! All donations will be rewarded based on the dollar amount contributed. Please see the section on Perks for more details. By contributing to our campaign and supporting ethical fashion, you are not only allowing IKURU to grow, you also have direct impact on the lives of these women and their families in Pemba. IKURU has achieved so much in the past year and can't wait to keep doing so. Thank you for your support!



Other Ways You Can Help

Every little step counts in helping IKURU empower and improve the lives of women in Pemba.

Help us spread the word by sharing our campaign with friends and family by using the indiegogo share tools! 

SHOP: By supporting ethical fashion, you have a direct role in empowering and improving the lives of women from vulnerable socio-economic sectors, their children and their communities. 

CONNECT: If you know of designers, investors, gender & health experts or enthusiasts, please put us in touch so we can share ideas, best practices and experiences. Or share your creative ideas of how you would like to help. We would love to hear from you.

SPREAD THE WORD: Share IKURUPROJECT and invite your friends on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and Pinterest to like our page, buy our clothing or follow our projects.

Visit us at:

http://www.ikuruproject.com/

http://ikuru.storenvy.com/

https://www.facebook.com/ikuruproject

https://twitter.com/ikuruproject

story:
"Neat chipboard wallet is cheap, green and functional.." -Cult of Mac

 "...you’ll still get a fair amount of satisfaction from putting together your own Chipwallet just the way you like it. -GearHungry

Chipwallet is a truly innovative wallet. It comes to you as a flat board with individual plates and an woven elastic band. It’s put together by you by simply releasing the plates from the board.

Chipwallet is a unique and totally different concept because it uses a common material in an unexpected way. Chipboard is a strong post-consumer recycled material typically used for shipping and packaging. Chipboard is durable, natural and sustainable. It looks great and feels great to the touch.

There’s something about putting a project together yourself, it brings a sense of ownership different from getting something off the shelf. It somehow become uniquely yours.

Chipwallet is beyond a product purchase, from the moment you receive it, it invites you to a process of making and transforming, a simple bonding perhaps with something you will carry every day.

 

A beautiful & simple idea

Durable & feels great to the touch

Each Chipwallet board contains 4 plates and a woven band for you to create your perfect wallet: 2 cover plates, a cash/miscellaneous plate and a plate for two standard house keys.You decide which plates you need and pop them out from the board. Use only the two cover plates with credit card access, or with a cash plate to carry your dollar bills, or with keys plate, or all together in your wallet.

Comes with 4 Interchangeable Plates

 

Cool, functional & innovative

 

Ultra-thin & slim

What makes Chipwallet different?      

  • Chipwallet is made from recycled material and has COOL DESIGN element to your everyday carry
  • Comes in a FLAT POP-OUT card that you put together
  • Modular. Included interchangeable plates let you configure and switch plates out to fit your daily carry style
  • Versatile & Slim. Carry up to 12 cards, keys and cash in a compact package
  • DRAW ON IT! Personalize it, you can draw on it. Tell your story, doodle, write and make a notes on it. Or, leave it blank

 

Customize what you carry for the day. Included interchangeable plates let you configure and switch plates out to fit your daily carry and access items you use most often. Each Chipwallet board has 4 plates, choose items you want to carry and insert the plate(s) to the wallet. You can carry credit cards, cash and keys, or just carry credit cards and cash, the choice is yours.

 

Configure plates for quick access items

Chipwallet's modular plates lets you decide which items you use most often and thus need direct access to. If you need quick access to keys, put that plate on the outside. If the keys are back up set, put the keys plate in-between the credit cards.

Same with cash, you can choose to have the cash plate as a hidden storage between your cards, or directly easily accessible from one side of the wallet. With the recessed design, your cash will not add bulk to the wallet.The plate is 1.2mm thick and will fit up to 4 folded dollar bills flushed.

Configuration A: Cover plates on both sides

 

Configuration B: Keys plate on one side

Configuration C: Cash/misc. plate on one side

 

The cash/miscellaneous card has a cavity perfect to fit one or a few folded dollar bills, memory cards like SD cards/SIM cards, mini membership cards, floss, or any other small flat items.

Cash plate fits coins, mini-cards & small flat items

 

Feature-packed in a Neat Package

 

Chipwallet is a minimalists' wallet at its core. So each element is carefully considered, designed and executed. The details are simple yet elegant and functional, and the material of the wallet complement that "less is more" philosophy. The texts on the plates are debossed and not printed.

Easy access to your cards from both sides

• Interchangeable plates let you choose what you want to carry each day

• Tiny and lightweight yet able to fit 2-12 cards, plus coins, keys and cash

• Arrives in a flat envelope, no unnecessary packaging

• Patent pending design 

Versatile & smart

 

A new innovation in monetary carriage

 

Ultra-lightweight and slim, say bye to the old ways of carrying your cards and cash. Chipwallet feels great in your hand and in your pocket because of its size and weight. You will not go back to the traditional wallet after experiencing Chipwallet. This is a wallet that you will love to carry everyday.

 

The process of making creates a bond, this is your wallet: use it, personalize it and when you are done, recycle it guilt-free.

Chipwallet will be made combining recycled materials, thoughtful design, and a stringent process that creates a beautiful, high quality product. The final product has natural feel and beautiful uniform finish.

Made with love & care

 

  Choose from 4 attractive color bands

Industrial grade high-density board (650-800kg/m3).

 

What is chipboard?

Chipboard is most commonly used in shipping boxes and packaging, made from recycled paper and wood waste. It is durable, strong and a beautiful material that feels great to the touch. It is also an incredibly honest material, our chipboard is natural and contains no dye and is 100% recyclable. Our elastic band is checkered woven from the highest quality cotton and polyester.

How strong is it?

We picked 1.2mm thick, high-density boards (650-800kg/m3). Chipboard is a proven material most commonly used to protect fragile items.

How durable is chipboard?

The chipboard we use is an industrial-grade chipboard. It is used in construction, car manufacturing and shipping. It's strong, lightweight and easy to work with.

Durable & Sustainable Material

 

Make it your own

Doodle on it, tell a story, gift it, go ahead. Draw a message and give it as a truly unique gift to your friends, family or loved ones. Tell a story or keep it blank, make it anyway you want it, make it about you.

 

The Design and Manufacturing Process       

Chipwallet is made from both dye-cut and laser cut parts. The texts on the plates are beautifully debossed. We first select the type of chipboards and density, from there the boards are cut into the final size and the individual plates are then die-cut and texts put in place.

Prototypes: We went through many iterations to find the perfect combination for the plate functions, various ways to hold the cards and items, and how to access them easily yet securely. We gave a few to some friends and they all love the look and feel of our lightweight wallet.

Prototypes

Early ideas include "themed plates" like Traveller's plate, Photogropher's plate, function specific plates that carry specific items like SD cards, SIM cards with paperclip and even coins cards. In the end, we decided to make the cash/miscellaneous card that can hold folded dollar bills and other flat items as it is the most versatile option.

Early Ideas

 

 

Risks and challenges

Even though we have designed a product that is aimed at simplicity of use and production, there will still be challenges and risks. We aim to manufacture this product in the United States, so we anticipate the cost to be higher. Another challenge is to make the product as high quality as possible, ensuring each and every detail, edge finish, and logo stamp looks great. Lastly will be adhering to the delivery schedule, we are at a very advanced prototype stage and have worked with vendors to ensure we allow enough lead time for tooling and set-up plus manufacturing/packaging time.

Durable & Sustainable Material
 


Make it your own
Doodle on it, tell a story, gift it, go ahead. Draw a message and give it as a truly unique gift to your friends, family or loved ones. Tell a story or keep it blank, make it anyway you want it, make it about you.

 
The Design and Manufacturing Process       
Chipwallet is made from both dye-cut and laser cut parts. The texts on the plates are beautifully debossed. We first select the type of chipboards and density, from there the boards are cut into the final size and the individual plates are then die-cut and texts put in place.
Prototypes: We went through many iterations to find the perfect combination for the plate functions, various ways to hold the cards and items, and how to access them easily yet securely. We gave a few to some friends and they all love the look and feel of our lightweight wallet.

Prototypes
Early ideas include "themed plates" like Traveller's plate, Photogropher's plate, function specific plates that carry specific items like SD cards, SIM cards with paperclip and even coins cards. In the end, we decided to make the cash/miscellaneous card that can hold folded dollar bills and other flat items as it is the most versatile option.

Early Ideas

 
 
Risks and challenges
Even though we have designed a product that is aimed at simplicity of use and production, there will still be challenges and risks. We aim to manufacture this product in the United States, so we anticipate the cost to be higher. Another challenge is to make the product as high quality as possible, ensuring each and every detail, edge finish, and logo stamp looks great. Lastly will be adhering to the delivery schedule, we are at a very advanced prototype stage and have worked with vendors to ensure we allow enough lead time for tooling and set-up plus manufacturing/packaging time.

story:
Avant-Garde Eyewear

Have you ever been walking around outside and realized that you need to clean the lenses on your sunglasses? Individual microfiber cloths can be very hard to keep track of while you are on the go. 

In the past, you would have to resort to using whatever cloth was available for cleaning, no matter how abrasive or ineffective. I asked myself: how can a pair of sunglasses be combined with the superior cleaning ability of microfiber material?

This question led to the creation of Ribbon Sunglasses.

How Do They Work?

Ribbon Sunglasses conceal a retractable microfiber cloth inside of the sunglass frame, allowing you to always have access to it no matter where you are. Microfiber is always the best solution for cleaning lenses, as it will never scratch or scuff the surface.

When you want to access the microfiber ribbon for cleaning, pull the recessed tab on the front of the frame. This tab allows you to extend the cloth. Run the cloth lightly over your lenses to clean away debris.

Once cleaning is completed, it is just as easy to get the ribbon back inside of the frame. Simply turn the thumb-wheel hidden in the corner of the frame until the ribbon is fully retracted. Once inside the frame, the ribbon is hidden completely from view.

Having a retractable microfiber cloth is a wonderful and very natural addition to a pair of sunglasses. It doesn't feel tacked on; it looks and feels completely integrated, as if it would improve the experience of any pair of eyewear. 

How Do They Look?

Short answer: they look GREAT.

The retractable ribbon has been built low profile into the corner of the frame. The functionality is so well integrated that it has been made invisible inside of the design. These sunglasses look very sharp.

The frame design was inspired by counter-culture imagery of the 1960s, mixed with sort of a new age appeal. Specifically, the frame recalls Ray-Ban's classic Wayfarer sunglasses, while at the same time having a slightly more modern, urban look. 

Materials and Construction

Ribbon Sunglasses not only bring new functionality to the realm of eyewear, they are also made using the highest quality materials to help promote long-term durability. Here is an overview of what will go into a pair...

Frame

The sunglass frame is made from injection molded polycarbonate plastic. This material gives the sunglasses a sturdy feel while also allowing them to wrap around and conform to your face. Polycarbonate plastics are an industry standard and are proven to last through a great number of uses without difficulty.

Lenses

The lenses begin with a polarized polycarbonate core, which is thermally fused to five additional layers. Two UV filtering layers block 100% of UVA and UVB ultraviolet rays up to 400 nanometers. The final outer layer consists of two scratch resistant films to help protect the lenses and keep them looking great.

Microfiber Cloth

The retractable microfiber cloth i'm using for the cleaning ribbon is the highest quality material available. The design required a very thin microfiber material, otherwise it wouldn't roll up tight enough to hide inside of the frame. It just so happened that the thinnest cloth was also the most effective at cleaning. A fiber weight of only .065 denier makes it almost twice as thin as other cleaning cloths on the market.

Production Plan

Currently, I have several working prototypes of the frame design. Small changes need to be made to the microfiber insert piece, including a magnetic tip on the ribbon's axle to help it stay in place inside of the frame cavity. These changes will take place in the 3D modeling suite, perhaps taking a couple of weeks to finalize. 

Once the changes are made to the CAD files, i'll begin working with one of several injection molding manufacturers that i'm in talks with around the LA metro. This stage that will be where we create the finalized production sunglasses. Once I have the parts injection molded and polished, they will be shipped out as soon as possible!

Perks

When you back Ribbon at one of the levels where you receive an actual pair of sunglasses, you will be contacted after the project to confirm which color microfiber ribbon should be included with your sunglasses. 

If you make a donation at any of the funding levels, i'll send you a digital version of Ribbon's development "process book". This book is going to be really cool, illustrated, and will take you through the entire process of what it has taken me to bring this product to market.

The perks are as follows:

  • $5: Backer-only updates and a digital process book
  • $25: T-shirt, backer-only updates and a digital process book
  • $60: Early-Bird Special - Sunglasses with microfiber of your color choice
  • $70: Classic - Sunglasses with microfiber of your color choice
  • $80: Trifecta - Sunglasses with microfiber in 3 colors of your color choice
  • $90: Kaleidoscope - Sunglasses with microfiber in ever color offered

Thanks so much for checking the project out. Please help support the creation of Ribbon Sunglasses!

story:
About this project

Why Progo:

  • The only carry-on backpack you need for traveling or carrying your camera gear. 
  •  Travel organized and keep your clothes wrinkle free and clean with the integrated removable shelf and dedicated shoe compartment. 
  •  Bluetooth anti-loss device gives you the peace of mind from theft or loss. 
  •  Charge all your electronics at once in your bag. Simply connect them to a power bar in your bag and plug the power bar cable to the wall socket via the dedicated zippered outlet at the bottom of the bag. 
  • Experience the comfort on the go.    

Featured on


ProGo Backpack just got better!

We have added the following features to the bag at no extra cost to our fellow backers:

 

Stretch goal #1 is now unlocked!

 Now you have the option to choose the ProGo backpack with your favorite zipper liner color. You will be able to choose in the survey sent to your after the campaign.


ProGo was created to make life easier for any traveler, no matter where, when and how.

 Did I hear Camera? 

ProGo is a perfect bag for Camera gear. It comes standard with 6 pieces of modular pads with Velcro and a pair of straps on the side for your Tripod. The front flap and the sides / back have enough padding to protect your gear.



Like to travel with some extra gear? We hear ya! For this you can have your Duffel bag as an add on for an extra $59

 

THE REASON I CREATED PROGO

I like to travel light. It is easier and lighter to carry just one backpack, and quicker by skipping the baggage claim section at the airport. But how can one carry all the necessary clothes, shoes and accessories including laptops and tablets in just one backpack? They just do not fit, unless you take a bulky luggage and drag it everywhere. That is just not me. To overcome the hassles and nightmares of luggage dragging, pack / unpacking, and having to jumble clean and dirty clothes with shoes; I have decided to create a very simple and unique travel backpack to solve all these problems and to be able to travel neat and clean; hence, I created ProGo.

ProGo is an intelligent & versatile travel carry-on backpack / luggage that meets all of your individual needs in one bag. Whatever your destination, whatever you need to carry, whatever mode of transport you take, ProGo will meet your needs.

 Progo is compact and yet spacious

The 35L backpack can easily accommodate a week's supply of clothes, a pair of shoes, a laptop and tablet, toiletry, personal accessories in their dedicated compartments as well as passports / valuables in the hidden pocket at the back. 

The main difference between Progo and other backpacks / carry ons, is that Progo has a built-in shelf which allows you to transfer your clothes from the bag to a closet in seconds. 


Why is ProGo unique?

Progo is no ordinary backpack. It's got 4 main features that NO other carrying bags have:  

1- Integrated removable shelf

 Here is how you pack a Progo:

1: Remove the shelf from the bag

 2: Hang it in your closet and fill it with your clothes

3: And put it back in the bag

ProGo is the only bag that  has a built in removable shelf. With this unique feature, you can transfer your belongings from Progo  to a closet in less than 10 seconds! 

Everything will be just as you packed them back home. Nice and crisp. 

2- A separate shoe compartment

Keep your dirty shoes away from your clean clothes

3- A safe hidden pouch at the back of the bag

You can keep your passport and valuable belongings in the hidden back pouch that will be impossible to reach when carrying the backpack, making sure that you will have a safe and smooth journey with your ProGo.

4: Bluetooth Device Tracker

Never lose your bag in the crowd

 

ProGo is also made of durable waterproof tarp material that  will  keep all your belongings dry in all weather conditions.

ProGo's name clearly says it. It's for people on the Go. Whether you are traveling around the block or the planet, ProGo will be your gear.

ProGo is a bag large enough to carry all your needs and compact enough to be a carry on

PROGO AND YOU

Why is ProGo right for you:

Because you travel 

Because you create

Because you explore

Prototyping:

Why the 1st prototype failed?

The first ProGo progotype had small separated external removable bag for toiletry and the shoe compartment was placed at the bottom of the bag. After using this prototype, I realized the 2 main issues.

First the removable bag was not holding strong and kept on falling. Also it made the bag thicker, so I could not fit it easily in the plane carry on compartment. The second issue, with the shoe compartment at the bottom;  the bag could not stand straight. It was always leaning and falling because the top part when full was heavier than the bottom part. So I was forced to re design and recreate a second prototype which you see in this video and the pictures. 

By moving the shoe compartment to the top, and ditching the removable bag, and making an internal toiletry pouch instead; the prototype proved to be right and working perfectly. 

Here are pictures of the Final prototypes

 The  right side of the bag has a  bottle mesh pouch and  Tripod / Umbrella holder straps. The left side of the bag has a  small accessory / key pocket, an extra handle as well as a USB cable outlet.

 The back of the bag that has the hidden pocket. Sunglasses holder and ear bud mesh pouch on shoulder straps

 USB cable outlet

 Toiletry bag at the front of the backpack

 Mesh pouch for cellphones or ear buds

Laptop / Tablet compartment with lots of business accessory / pen holders

What's Progo Made of?

Progo will be built with heavy duty waterproof tarp nylon fabric (these are the materials that trucking companies use to protect goods from getting wet) , water proof sealed seamless  zippers with over size pullers and nylon strings, as well as padded frame/ walls and straps with durable and strong nylon webbing. Progo has been designed to last millions of miles. 

Time Frame:

  • February: Indiegogo Indemand
  • April-May : Production and QC
  • June: Shipment and Delivery

Your support

In order to bring the Progo Bags to your life and make your travels smoother, we need to meet our factory's minimum order quantity requirement; and this will only be possible with your support. By making a pledge, you will secure yourself the best travel bag in the world and use it in good health for a very long time…now that’s priceless... Thank you.

Thank you

Thank you all for taking your time to view this project . We hope that you are as passionate and excited as we are about Progo Bags.

Please spread the word and share this project with your friends and loved ones.

Risks and challenges

We have already found a very reputable bag and luggage factory that has helped us making our prototypes. The communication with the factory had been smooth and fast, which reduces the risks of manufacturing and delivery time substantially. Nevertheless we have set the delivery time in June  of 2016 to make sure that all backers will receive their bags on time as promised. This will give us more time to overcome any problems that might occur during manufacturing or delivery. 
To ensure that every bag is created to standard and delivered in time, we will be maintaining constant contact with the factory during the entire process of production. No matter what, we will update our backers during the production.

story:
UPDATE: Thanks to our friends and supporters, our project has met it's goal and will be moving forward. We couldn't be more thrilled! We plan to have an official launch in mid-September. 

We have moved to InDemand status, meaning all of our perks are still available. You can still support the project, sponsor a portion of the lab, and pre-register for membership. We will be updating this page soon to reflect the new phase of crowdfunding, but in the meantime, please feel free to share or select any perk still listed. 

Scarves and boxers will be available as thank-you gifts through the end of August. Membership deals will be available until our launch date (TBA).

Thank you, Portland! Your support has been amazing and we love you!!

Hi, I’m Dawn Moothart, founder of Portland Apparel Lab (PAL). For 4 years, I have run my own company, specializing in sewn-goods product development. I work with designers and innovators throughout the Portland region to help get their prototypes built and ready for manufacturing. I co-founded the Portland Apparel Lab in 2014, recognizing that despite a talent-rich and diverse apparel design community in Portland, the city remains resource-poor and lacks the services, resources and valued industry relationships necessary to launch and grow successful brands.

Hi, I’m Kelley Roy, Founder and Owner of ADX and Portland Made. I’ve been working for 5 years to grow Portland’s Maker Movement. I consult with people from around the world to create Makerspaces, like ADX, in their communities. I have become a globally recognized leader in the Maker Movement and I’m helping to put Portland Makers on the international map. My passion is helping creatives hone their skills, start their own businesses, and make a living doing what they love.

We are joining forces to launch the Portland Apparel Lab.

The Problem

Portland is bursting with creative talent. But few resources exist to support designers as entrepreneurs. You can rent a studio, but that’s really just an empty box. When pattern software alone starts at $10,000, you can easily find yourself spending $20,000 or more just to outfit your workspace. Portland lacks a garment district, or even a true wholesaler for fabric. You can spend weeks, even months, tracking down machines, labels, zippers and fabric from all over the United States. And after all that, you’ll still be working alone, by yourself, in your box.

What if there was somewhere you could go to find the equipment and connections you need to get your apparel business off the ground? The Portland Apparel Lab (PAL) is that place.

The Solution

PAL is a 2000 square foot collaborative makerspace designed to accelerate your apparel business. More than just a workspace with industrial tools, PAL is the hub of an ecosystem, connecting you to the materials and services you need to start or grow your brand. And we’ve partnered with ADX to make it happen.

ADX is Portland’s makerspace for wood, metal and other hard goods. For 5 years they have helped launch over 100 companies from their 14,000 square foot facility and provided them access to the tools, space and professional expertise to start and grow their companies.

For the last 3 years, people have been asking, “when will Portland have an ADX for fashion?”

We can proudly say the answer is “now!” with your help.

What We Need

We have secured a 2000 square foot space in the heart of the Central Eastside Industrial District, next door to ADX, Portland's Makerspace. $10,000 will help us secure a few different pieces of equipment and pre-register members, so we can open our doors in September 2016.

We have 60% of the equipment we need to open, but will use campaign funds to buy a few more vital tools and machines. If the campaign exceeds the basics, our stretch goals include three key tools: a button hole machine, a flatlock machine and coverstitch machine. 

What You Can Get

We are seeking to pre-sell memberships through the campaign, including 50 Community level memberships, 45 Explorer level memberships and 50 Accelerator level membership applications.

Community Membership is intended for anyone who simply wants access to the community of creatives for networking and business support. Community members will get free access to events and discounted access to classes and production services. This level includes the ability to purchase a day pass to the workspace.

Professional Membership is for companies or individuals who already have established brands, studio spaces and most of the equipment you need. Your team may just need access to our specialty equipment and want to be part of the community of professionals. Regular Pro membership will be $95/month and $35/hour for equipment rental which will can be reserved any day, any time, once users have completed the member orientation and safety training.

Explorer Membership is intended for individuals who would like to explore their creative pursuits in a professional environment. Explorers get unlimited access to the prototyping studio, digital lab and materials library during “Open Studio” hours (five 4-hour sessions per week), as well as discounted access to classes and free entry to events. Day passes may be available for purchase during non-Open Studio hours, space permitting.

Accelerator Membership is intended for brands that are ready to launch or grow to their businesses. We will have 10 spots open at launch for Accelerator Members through an application process. Accelerators will have unlimited access to everything in the Lab during all operational hours and the ability to schedule time on specific Lab equipment. Accelerator Membership includes exclusive product and service discounts, mentorship opportunities, and access to our extensive partnership network of professional service providers. Once you have been accepted to the Accelerator Program, you will be assessed monthly membership dues ($575/month). We ask that you commit to at least 6 months in the Accelerator Program.

We have also developed a few Thank You Gifts for those backers who think this is a just a fantastic idea and would like to see it happen. See the Gallery Tab above for photos of our Swag.

The Impact of our Project

Portland is primed and ready for a fashion incubator. For 5 years, ADX has built and operated a successful makerspace with a financially viable business model. Their unique combination of tools and service, enables them to launch entrepreneurs making physical goods.  As our primary business partner, ADX will help us achieve success in a much shorter timeframe by applying lessons they have learned.

PAL is essentially an ADX for soft goods production. The needs are the same: physical space, tools and professional guidance for starting and growing successful businesses. We will apply the same revenue model including membership, classes and production services, to create a financially stable company that can continue to serve you for years to come.

By pre-registering for membership you will secure your spot in the PAL community and be ready to take your skills and businesses to the next level among a cohort of other talented individuals. We are limiting the number of memberships at each level to make sure that we can offer our services in the most effective manner. Get your membership now and be ready to go in September 2016!

As many of us know, the infrastructure for textiles and soft goods in Portland have all but disappeared over the past 20 years. Fortunately places like Spooltown, Portland Garment Factory and NW Alpine have started to bring back small batch production, and entrepreneurs like Studio 317, Modhouse and JLD Studios have started offering prototyping and production services for a variety of brands. Retailers like WildFang have garnered international brand loyalty with their own line of tomboy apparel, and are bringing attention to Portland’s hot fashion design scene. FashioNXT is producing a top shelf fashion show focused on interactive apparel. Brands like Society 9, Handful, Poler and Bridge & Burn are elevating Portland’s soft goods scene, but many of these products cannot be produced locally because of the lack of infrastructure. This is a longer term problem that the community needs to work on over the next 10 - 15 years. PAL will quickly become a HUB for the community and allow us to work together to rebuild the ecosystem while providing badly needed services that are currently missing from the marketplace.

Our Challenges

Starting and growing a business is not easy. By creating a space that offers tools, classes, services and a community of support, we help remove the barriers to help you accelerate your success. And the cool thing is, our success is your success. We are invested in each other, and our goals are the same: help brands launch high quality products at a size and scale that fits the market. It is challenging to find affordable real estate in Portland’s hot real estate market, but we have fortunately secured an ideal 2000 square foot space right next door to ADX on SE 11th and Stark. The space is perfect with lots of natural light, separate but connected production pods, a comfy lounge area with a small kitchen, conference room and easy access to the larger community of support at ADX.

Other Ways To Help

Help us spread the word by becoming a PAL Advocate and sharing the campaign with your network on your social media and at events. We will add you to our list of Advocates and acknowledge your hard work helping us get off the ground.Use the IndieGogo share tools to share the campaign with designers that you think will join as members!

We are stronger together.
Let's make this happen!
Thanks so much for your support. 
Video Credit: Mikee Shattuck, Copywriting: Erin Frank, Still Photography: Aaron Lee, Graphic Design: Dani Ramsby
story_txt:
UPDATE: Thanks to our friends and supporters, our project has met it's goal and will be moving forward. We couldn't be more thrilled! We plan to have an official launch in mid-September. We have moved to InDemand status, meaning all of our perks are still available. You can still support the project, sponsor a portion of the lab, and pre-register for membership. We will be updating this page soon to reflect the new phase of crowdfunding, but in the meantime, please feel free to share or select any perk still listed. Scarves and boxers will be available as thank-you gifts through the end of August. Membership deals will be available until our launch date (TBA).Thank you, Portland! Your support has been amazing and we love you!!Hi, I’m Dawn Moothart, founder of Portland Apparel Lab (PAL). For 4 years, I have run my own company, specializing in sewn-goods product development. I work with designers and innovators throughout the Portland region to help get their prototypes built and ready for manufacturing. I co-founded the Portland Apparel Lab in 2014, recognizing that despite a talent-rich and diverse apparel design community in Portland, the city remains resource-poor and lacks the services, resources and valued industry relationships necessary to launch and grow successful brands.Hi, I’m Kelley Roy, Founder and Owner of ADX and Portland Made. I’ve been working for 5 years to grow Portland’s Maker Movement. I consult with people from around the world to create Makerspaces, like ADX, in their communities. I have become a globally recognized leader in the Maker Movement and I’m helping to put Portland Makers on the international map. My passion is helping creatives hone their skills, start their own businesses, and make a living doing what they love.We are joining forces to launch the Portland Apparel Lab.The ProblemPortland is bursting with creative talent. But few resources exist to support designers as entrepreneurs. You can rent a studio, but that’s really just an empty box. When pattern software alone starts at $10,000, you can easily find yourself spending $20,000 or more just to outfit your workspace. Portland lacks a garment district, or even a true wholesaler for fabric. You can spend weeks, even months, tracking down machines, labels, zippers and fabric from all over the United States. And after all that, you’ll still be working alone, by yourself, in your box.What if there was somewhere you could go to find the equipment and connections you need to get your apparel business off the ground? The Portland Apparel Lab (PAL) is that place.The SolutionPAL is a 2000 square foot collaborative makerspace designed to accelerate your apparel business. More than just a workspace with industrial tools, PAL is the hub of an ecosystem, connecting you to the materials and services you need to start or grow your brand. And we’ve partnered with ADX to make it happen.ADX is Portland’s makerspace for wood, metal and other hard goods. For 5 years they have helped launch over 100 companies from their 14,000 square foot facility and provided them access to the tools, space and professional expertise to start and grow their companies.For the last 3 years, people have been asking, “when will Portland have an ADX for fashion?”We can proudly say the answer is “now!” with your help.What We NeedWe have secured a 2000 square foot space in the heart of the Central Eastside Industrial District, next door to ADX, Portland's Makerspace. $10,000 will help us secure a few different pieces of equipment and pre-register members, so we can open our doors in September 2016.We have 60% of the equipment we need to open, but will use campaign funds to buy a few more vital tools and machines. If the campaign exceeds the basics, our stretch goals include three key tools: a button hole machine, a flatlock machine and coverstitch machine. What You Can GetWe are seeking to pre-sell memberships through the campaign, including 50 Community level memberships, 45 Explorer level memberships and 50 Accelerator level membership applications.Community Membership is intended for anyone who simply wants access to the community of creatives for networking and business support. Community members will get free access to events and discounted access to classes and production services. This level includes the ability to purchase a day pass to the workspace.Professional Membership is for companies or individuals who already have established brands, studio spaces and most of the equipment you need. Your team may just need access to our specialty equipment and want to be part of the community of professionals. Regular Pro membership will be $95/month and $35/hour for equipment rental which will can be reserved any day, any time, once users have completed the member orientation and safety training.Explorer Membership is intended for individuals who would like to explore their creative pursuits in a professional environment. Explorers get unlimited access to the prototyping studio, digital lab and materials library during “Open Studio” hours (five 4-hour sessions per week), as well as discounted access to classes and free entry to events. Day passes may be available for purchase during non-Open Studio hours, space permitting.Accelerator Membership is intended for brands that are ready to launch or grow to their businesses. We will have 10 spots open at launch for Accelerator Members through an application process. Accelerators will have unlimited access to everything in the Lab during all operational hours and the ability to schedule time on specific Lab equipment. Accelerator Membership includes exclusive product and service discounts, mentorship opportunities, and access to our extensive partnership network of professional service providers. Once you have been accepted to the Accelerator Program, you will be assessed monthly membership dues ($575/month). We ask that you commit to at least 6 months in the Accelerator Program.We have also developed a few Thank You Gifts for those backers who think this is a just a fantastic idea and would like to see it happen. See the Gallery Tab above for photos of our Swag.The Impact of our ProjectPortland is primed and ready for a fashion incubator. For 5 years, ADX has built and operated a successful makerspace with a financially viable business model. Their unique combination of tools and service, enables them to launch entrepreneurs making physical goods.  As our primary business partner, ADX will help us achieve success in a much shorter timeframe by applying lessons they have learned.PAL is essentially an ADX for soft goods production. The needs are the same: physical space, tools and professional guidance for starting and growing successful businesses. We will apply the same revenue model including membership, classes and production services, to create a financially stable company that can continue to serve you for years to come.By pre-registering for membership you will secure your spot in the PAL community and be ready to take your skills and businesses to the next level among a cohort of other talented individuals. We are limiting the number of memberships at each level to make sure that we can offer our services in the most effective manner. Get your membership now and be ready to go in September 2016!As many of us know, the infrastructure for textiles and soft goods in Portland have all but disappeared over the past 20 years. Fortunately places like Spooltown, Portland Garment Factory and NW Alpine have started to bring back small batch production, and entrepreneurs like Studio 317, Modhouse and JLD Studios have started offering prototyping and production services for a variety of brands. Retailers like WildFang have garnered international brand loyalty with their own line of tomboy apparel, and are bringing attention to Portland’s hot fashion design scene. FashioNXT is producing a top shelf fashion show focused on interactive apparel. Brands like Society 9, Handful, Poler and Bridge & Burn are elevating Portland’s soft goods scene, but many of these products cannot be produced locally because of the lack of infrastructure. This is a longer term problem that the community needs to work on over the next 10 - 15 years. PAL will quickly become a HUB for the community and allow us to work together to rebuild the ecosystem while providing badly needed services that are currently missing from the marketplace.Our ChallengesStarting and growing a business is not easy. By creating a space that offers tools, classes, services and a community of support, we help remove the barriers to help you accelerate your success. And the cool thing is, our success is your success. We are invested in each other, and our goals are the same: help brands launch high quality products at a size and scale that fits the market. It is challenging to find affordable real estate in Portland’s hot real estate market, but we have fortunately secured an ideal 2000 square foot space right next door to ADX on SE 11th and Stark. The space is perfect with lots of natural light, separate but connected production pods, a comfy lounge area with a small kitchen, conference room and easy access to the larger community of support at ADX.Other Ways To HelpHelp us spread the word by becoming a PAL Advocate and sharing the campaign with your network on your social media and at events. We will add you to our list of Advocates and acknowledge your hard work helping us get off the ground.Use the IndieGogo share tools to share the campaign with designers that you think will join as members!



We are stronger together.Let's make this happen!Thanks so much for your support. Video Credit: Mikee Shattuck, Copywriting: Erin Frank, Still Photography: Aaron Lee, Graphic Design: Dani Ramsby

story:
We’ve been in the wool business for 8 years. Our complete line of high blend premium merino clothing in everyday styles at reasonable prices is designed to make a full wool life possible. Thousands of repeat customers and crowdfunding backers have already joined us in our mission to ditch synthetics for high performance all-natural wool, join the flock! 

 

 

In 2019, Woolly delivered the Longhaul pants.  Thank you to the 1850 backers that made this project a success and helped create a merino wool version of your everyday pants. Check out our Longhaul campaign!
